THE PH. D. OCTOPUS.
A Reply to Professor James from the Point of View of the Octopus.
ROFESSOR WILLIAM JAMES, in a recent number of the Harvard
Monthly, has criticized the worship of the public for the degree of Doctor
of Philosophy. It is, he says, a sort of "mandarin disease" hostile to our
democratic idea that it is the man and the man's ability that count. The criticism
is not new. Montaigue about three centuries ago, though he did not speak
specifically of the doctor's degree, made essentially similar restrictions concerning
the worship of perfunctory knowledge, while the dangers of any hard and fast
system have been pointed out by almost every philosopher who has wielded a pen
in behalf of education. Nevertheless the degree has survived, although it has
several times changed its significance.
Originally Master, Professor, and Doctor were used interchangeably. It
was not until sometime after the degrees in law, divinity, and medicine had
become established as signs of the completion of an adequate training in these
subjects, that the conviction arose that it was as foolish and dangerous to leave
the training of a teacher, as it was to leave that of a doctor, to the whims and
vagaries of an irregular education. While the one might prove a menace to his
patient's health, the other might become a sower of heresy. Consequently the
terms Master and Doctor were officialized as signs of an adequate training. In
America to-day we are going through a similar evolution. Only the heresy
which we now fear is of another kind, the heresy of ignorance.
The exceptional man will now, as always, be amenable to no system and will
reach his ends by exceptional ways. So far as he is concerned, Professor James's
strictures are rational enough. But such men are rare, and the demand for
teachers has to-day. increased far beyond the supply of native genius. There
are about four hundred colleges in America. To expect to find in every one men
of high native ability is futile.
How then shall the average teacher be selected. The college should, says
Professor James, apply to his instructors for recommendations. This, so far as
the teacher's learning is concerned, is a mere play on words. For the doctor's
degree, as it is conferred on the usual graduate student, is for the most part only
an official recommendation of the adequacy of his knowledge in the subject which
he is to teach. And the adequacy of his knowledge is the first of all considerations. Another man, says Professor James, may be more learned. Very true;
but the only test by which one may know it is the examination. In Germany,
where this is recognized, the passing of the itaatsexamen is required of every
would-be teacher; just as we require state examinations of physicians or lawyers.

In America, for collegiate teachers, the only such examinations we have are those
for the doctor's degree.
There is, however, a second requisite for a teacher, high scientific or academic
ideals. And these can in most cases be, for the average man, attained only where
he is surrounded by them. As Professor Rowland once said:
"He" (the student) "goes forth into the world, and the height to which he
rises has been influenced by the ideals which he has consciously or unconsciously
imbibed in his university. If the professors under whom he has studied have been
high in their profession, and have themselves had high ideals; if they have considered the advance of their particular subject their highest work in life, and are
themselves honored for their intellect throughout the world,—the student is
drawn toward that which is highest, and ever after in life has high ideals."
This association with high ideals can, in the sphere of academic knowledge,
be attained only within the walls of our large universities. The first requirements
then for a teacher are that he shall spend some time in such circles and that he
shall be examined officially as to his knowledge. And this is just what a candidate
for the doctor's degree does. And the fact that he has done this is all that is'meant
by the conferring of the degree. For the thesis is only another form of testing
his knowledge and intellectual power. If then the candidate has complied with
these conditions, the distinction, so far as the spirit and substance of his learning
is concerned, between recommendation by the word of his instructors and recommendation by an official degree is meaningless.
Professor James, however, makes the point that the man should be a good
teacher. Apropos of which we may quote further from Professor Rowland:
"But if the student is taught by what are sometimes called good teachers, and
teachers only, who know little more than the student, and who are often surpassed
and even despised by him, no one can doubt the lowered tone of his mind."
This may be a little strong ; but it emphasizes the subordinate importance of
ability to teach in and by itself. It must be admitted that. Professor James is
partially right on the point ; but the enduring • part of his argument, after the
cloak of anecdote and wit is stripped off, is simply this, that a teacher should
know how to teach, a conclusion which seems scarcely new enough to be worthy
of so long and able a defense.
Professor James, however, holds up to us several horrible examples, such as
the colleges which advertise the degrees of their.faculty. as the "brazen mercantile
fashion" advertises soap or historical novels,, the colleges that advertise "No
teachers here who are not doctors,- and the men who have taken degrees in one
subject and then, on the strength of the degrees, taught something else. There
is only one reply to such arguments. As a rule these things do not exist; and
the trotting them forth as flagrant examples of corruption is a sin as flagrant, in
its own way, as the sins these examples are to illustrate. It is a sin against the
ancient principle of logic which forbids generalizing from exceptions, however
entertaining it may be.
Professor James furthermore laments the damage done to the doctor's
degree by making it a commercial necessity, instead of a free recognition of

N view of the recent publications in the daily press regarding the failure of the
University of Pennsylvania lacrosse team to fulfill its date with Hopkins
on April 4th, it seems well to the editors that the position of the University
in regard to the matter be plainly stated.
The facts are doubtless known to all: The date was made in good faith
by the Hopkins management, duly advertised, and in spite of very threatening
weather early in the day several hundred people assembled to witness the opening
game of the season. Their interest was rewarded by the statement, made at the
grounds on the authority of a telegram received at one o'clock that Pennsylvania
would not be down on account of rain in Philadelphia. The coaches hastily
assembled an "All Baltimore" team to play against the varsity, and pulled off a
very creditable game considering the adverse circumstances.
By just what mental process the management at Philadelphia reached their
conclusion has not yet been fully made clear. The contract included an ample
guarantee in case of rain, they were aware of the fact that the game had been
advertised and also, probably, of the fact that Lacrosse may be played in the
rain. The only explanation forthcoming as to their somewhat peculiar method
of keeping dates was contained in the original message. Up to this time no
apology, explanation, or offer to meet the actual financial loss to the Hopkins
management, has been received.
So much for the facts. Now as to the University's position in the matter.
The Athlete Association feels that the reason advanced—Rain in Philadelphia—is
not sufficient to justify the cancelling of a financial contract involving loss to the
other party. It feels that the Pennsylvania team showed lack of sportsmanlike
courtesy in withdrawing at the eleventh hour on the ground named. And lastly
it feels that some apology is due to it for this rather unusual treatment, or at
least an offer to share the loss incurred in the matter.
The last letter received from the Pensylvania management, complaining
of the tone of the comments of the daily papers on the incident, hardly deserves
notice in these columns. It is enough to say that neither the team, management
nor coaches are responsible for all statements appearing in the daily papers.

ORK on the intercollegiate debate has been progressing rapidly since

team. The men are training every (lay and anyone who can furnish an argument

BASE BALL TEAM DISBANDS.

FTER a brief existence of a few weeks, it has been ultimately decided to
disband the baseball team. This decision was reathed only after a serious
consideration of the circumstances that seemed to render such action necessary. Certain causes which had been operating since the beginning of the season, at last became of such a nature that disorganization seemed the most advisable
course to pursue. To this end all games scheduled have been cancelled. The
causes referred to will probably occur to everyone at all familiar with the baseball
situation. From the first the team has been surfeited with disappointments. Practice began encouragingly with a promising bunch of candidates, but this number
was soon to be decreased by unforseen circumstances. Two men had attacks of
sickness that would have prevented them from playing again this season. Another man was compelled to withdraw on account of outside work, several others
on account of studies, while three more were seriously handicapped by the pressure
brought to bear upon them in other lines of athletics. Despite these drawbacks, a full team and several substitutes were left, but increasing studies of the
medical men who form a majority of the team, rendered practice very inconvenient,
although it called for only one hour on two afternoons a week, which were
the only times any number of the men'could be got together. In this limited
time, results could not be assured that would justify the inconveniences suffered
in sparing the time for practice. The enthusiasm of the players was valueless
when unaccompanied by opportunity to practice. Furthermore, the lack of favorable interest, as well as the unabated discouragement of the Athletic Board
was not calculated to add to the success of a team. There seems to be a prevailing prejudice against a Hopkins baseball team that cannot well be overcome
under existing conditions. What the future of baseball at the Hopkins may be,
it is impossible at this time to say, but very certain it is that until suitable and
convenient grounds can be procured for practice and playing, a movement to establish baseball again will labor under great difficulties.

THE PH. D. OCTOPUS.
A Reply to Professor James from the Point of View of the Octopus.
ROFESSOR WILLIAM JAMES, in a recent number of the Harvard
Monthly, has criticized the worship of the public for the degree of Doctor
of Philosophy. It is, he says, a sort of "mandarin disease" hostile to our
democratic idea that it is the man and the man's ability that count. The criticism
is not new. Montaigue about three centuries ago, though he did not speak
specifically of the doctor's degree, made essentially similar restrictions concerning
the worship of perfunctory knowledge, while the dangers of any hard and fast
system have been pointed out by almost every philosopher who has wielded a pen
in behalf of education. Nevertheless the degree has survived, although it has
several times changed its significance.
Originally Master, Professor, and Doctor were used interchangeably. It
was not until sometime after the degrees in law, divinity, and medicine had
become established as signs of the completion of an adequate training in these
subjects, that the conviction arose that it was as foolish and dangerous to leave
the training of a teacher, as it was to leave that of a doctor, to the whims and
vagaries of an irregular education. While the one might prove a menace to his
patient's health, the other might become a sower of heresy. Consequently the
terms Master and Doctor were officialized as signs of an adequate training. In
America to-day we are going through a similar evolution. Only the heresy
which we now fear is of another kind, the heresy of ignorance.
The exceptional man will now, as always, be amenable to no system and will
reach his ends by exceptional ways. So far as he is concerned, Professor James's
strictures are rational enough. But such men are rare, and the demand for
teachers has to-day. increased far beyond the supply of native genius. There
are about four hundred colleges in America. To expect to find in every one men
of high native ability is futile.
How then shall the average teacher be selected. The college should, says
Professor James, apply to his instructors for recommendations. This, so far as
the teacher's learning is concerned, is a mere play on words. For the doctor's
degree, as it is conferred on the usual graduate student, is for the most part only
an official recommendation of the adequacy of his knowledge in the subject which
he is to teach. And the adequacy of his knowledge is the first of all considerations. Another man, says Professor James, may be more learned. Very true;
but the only test by which one may know it is the examination. In Germany,
where this is recognized, the passing of the itaatsexamen is required of every
would-be teacher; just as we require state examinations of physicians or lawyers.

In America, for collegiate teachers, the only such examinations we have are those
for the doctor's degree.
There is, however, a second requisite for a teacher, high scientific or academic
ideals. And these can in most cases be, for the average man, attained only where
he is surrounded by them. As Professor Rowland once said:
"He" (the student) "goes forth into the world, and the height to which he
rises has been influenced by the ideals which he has consciously or unconsciously
imbibed in his university. If the professors under whom he has studied have been
high in their profession, and have themselves had high ideals; if they have considered the advance of their particular subject their highest work in life, and are
themselves honored for their intellect throughout the world,—the student is
drawn toward that which is highest, and ever after in life has high ideals."
This association with high ideals can, in the sphere of academic knowledge,
be attained only within the walls of our large universities. The first requirements
then for a teacher are that he shall spend some time in such circles and that he
shall be examined officially as to his knowledge. And this is just what a candidate
for the doctor's degree does. And the fact that he has done this is all that is'meant
by the conferring of the degree. For the thesis is only another form of testing
his knowledge and intellectual power. If then the candidate has complied with
these conditions, the distinction, so far as the spirit and substance of his learning
is concerned, between recommendation by the word of his instructors and recommendation by an official degree is meaningless.
Professor James, however, makes the point that the man should be a good
teacher. Apropos of which we may quote further from Professor Rowland:
"But if the student is taught by what are sometimes called good teachers, and
teachers only, who know little more than the student, and who are often surpassed
and even despised by him, no one can doubt the lowered tone of his mind."
This may be a little strong ; but it emphasizes the subordinate importance of
ability to teach in and by itself. It must be admitted that. Professor James is
partially right on the point ; but the enduring • part of his argument, after the
cloak of anecdote and wit is stripped off, is simply this, that a teacher should
know how to teach, a conclusion which seems scarcely new enough to be worthy
of so long and able a defense.
Professor James, however, holds up to us several horrible examples, such as
the colleges which advertise the degrees of their.faculty. as the "brazen mercantile
fashion" advertises soap or historical novels,, the colleges that advertise "No
teachers here who are not doctors,- and the men who have taken degrees in one
subject and then, on the strength of the degrees, taught something else. There
is only one reply to such arguments. As a rule these things do not exist; and
the trotting them forth as flagrant examples of corruption is a sin as flagrant, in
its own way, as the sins these examples are to illustrate. It is a sin against the
ancient principle of logic which forbids generalizing from exceptions, however
entertaining it may be.
Professor James furthermore laments the damage done to the doctor's
degree by making it a commercial necessity, instead of a free recognition of

N view of the recent publications in the daily press regarding the failure of the
University of Pennsylvania lacrosse team to fulfill its date with Hopkins
on April 4th, it seems well to the editors that the position of the University
in regard to the matter be plainly stated.
The facts are doubtless known to all: The date was made in good faith
by the Hopkins management, duly advertised, and in spite of very threatening
weather early in the day several hundred people assembled to witness the opening
game of the season. Their interest was rewarded by the statement, made at the
grounds on the authority of a telegram received at one o'clock that Pennsylvania
would not be down on account of rain in Philadelphia. The coaches hastily
assembled an "All Baltimore" team to play against the varsity, and pulled off a
very creditable game considering the adverse circumstances.
By just what mental process the management at Philadelphia reached their
conclusion has not yet been fully made clear. The contract included an ample
guarantee in case of rain, they were aware of the fact that the game had been
advertised and also, probably, of the fact that Lacrosse may be played in the
rain. The only explanation forthcoming as to their somewhat peculiar method
of keeping dates was contained in the original message. Up to this time no
apology, explanation, or offer to meet the actual financial loss to the Hopkins
management, has been received.
So much for the facts. Now as to the University's position in the matter.
The Athlete Association feels that the reason advanced—Rain in Philadelphia—is
not sufficient to justify the cancelling of a financial contract involving loss to the
other party. It feels that the Pennsylvania team showed lack of sportsmanlike
courtesy in withdrawing at the eleventh hour on the ground named. And lastly
it feels that some apology is due to it for this rather unusual treatment, or at
least an offer to share the loss incurred in the matter.
The last letter received from the Pensylvania management, complaining
of the tone of the comments of the daily papers on the incident, hardly deserves
notice in these columns. It is enough to say that neither the team, management
nor coaches are responsible for all statements appearing in the daily papers.

Several times time was called owing to a man being laid up temporarily. After
ten minutes of such playing, the Stevens men weakened considerably, and the
'Varsity had it easy from then on.
The only scoring by the visitors was during- that ten minutes of fast playing.
The ball went slowly from Stevens' goal toward Hopkins'. Roeser passed the
ball to Johnson, who threw safely past P. Strauss.
For the past two years Stevens has been excluded from the league on account
of alleged roughness, but it must be said to their credit that they put up a clean
but fast game. They came with the intention and expectation of winning, but
they did not let their desire cause them to use any undue roughness in attaining
their aim. That they did not win was because they were outclassed by Hopkins.
Some of the 'Varsity boys distinguished themselves on the field, hut the victory was due to the good work of the team as a whole. The old men, of course,
could be relied upon to do their share of work, but some misgivings were felt as
to the ability of the new ones to put up such an article as is demanded if we are
to win the championship again this year. It must be said that the new men
accredited themselves with glory. Keep it up, boys, and old Johns Hopkins will
add another championship banner to her already long list.

BASE BALL TEAM DISBANDS.

FTER a brief existence of a few weeks, it has been ultimately decided to
disband the baseball team. This decision was reathed only after a serious
consideration of the circumstances that seemed to render such action necessary. Certain causes which had been operating since the beginning of the season, at last became of such a nature that disorganization seemed the most advisable
course to pursue. To this end all games scheduled have been cancelled. The
causes referred to will probably occur to everyone at all familiar with the baseball
situation. From the first the team has been surfeited with disappointments. Practice began encouragingly with a promising bunch of candidates, but this number
was soon to be decreased by unforseen circumstances. Two men had attacks of
sickness that would have prevented them from playing again this season. Another man was compelled to withdraw on account of outside work, several others
on account of studies, while three more were seriously handicapped by the pressure
brought to bear upon them in other lines of athletics. Despite these drawbacks, a full team and several substitutes were left, but increasing studies of the
medical men who form a majority of the team, rendered practice very inconvenient,
although it called for only one hour on two afternoons a week, which were
the only times any number of the men'could be got together. In this limited
time, results could not be assured that would justify the inconveniences suffered
in sparing the time for practice. The enthusiasm of the players was valueless
when unaccompanied by opportunity to practice. Furthermore, the lack of favorable interest, as well as the unabated discouragement of the Athletic Board
was not calculated to add to the success of a team. There seems to be a prevailing prejudice against a Hopkins baseball team that cannot well be overcome
under existing conditions. What the future of baseball at the Hopkins may be,
it is impossible at this time to say, but very certain it is that until suitable and
convenient grounds can be procured for practice and playing, a movement to establish baseball again will labor under great difficulties.
